title: ‚ÄòChristian pastors declared Pikachu to be a demon‚Äô: how Pok√©mon went from moral panic to unifying global hit
description:
Nintendo‚Äôs monster-collecting franchise was pilloried as a ‚Äòpestilential Ponzi scheme‚Äô in the 90s. But as its celebrates its 30th birthday, it now stands as a powerful example of video games‚Äô ability to connect people
When I was 11, it was my dream to compete in the Pok√©mon World Championships, held in Sydney in 2000. I‚Äôd come across it in a magazine, and then earnestly set about training teams of creatures, transferring them between my Pok√©mon Red Game Boy cartridge and the 3D arenas of Pok√©mon Stadium on the Nintendo 64. I never made it as a player but I did finally achieve this dream on my 26th birthday, when I went to Washington DC to cover the world championships as a journalist. I was deeply moved.
fullText:
Nintendo‚Äôs monster-collecting franchise was pilloried as a ‚Äòpestilential Ponzi scheme‚Äô in the 90s. But as its celebrates its 30th birthday, it now stands as a powerful example of video games‚Äô ability to connect people

When I was 11, it was my dream to compete in the Pok√©mon World Championships, held in Sydney in 2000. I‚Äôd come across it in a magazine, and then earnestly set about training teams of creatures, transferring them between my Pok√©mon Red Game Boy cartridge and the 3D arenas of Pok√©mon Stadium on the Nintendo 64. I never made it as a player but I did finally achieve this dream on my 26th birthday, when I went to Washington DC to cover the world championships as a journalist. I was deeply moved. Presided over by a giant inflatable Pikachu hanging from the ceiling, the competitors and spectators were united in an unselfconscious love for these games, with their colourful menageries and heartfelt messaging about trust, friendship and hard work.

It is emotional to see the winners lift¬†their trophies after a tense final round of battles, as overwhelmed by their success as any sportsperson. But it‚Äôs the pride that the smaller competitors‚Äô parents show in their mini champions that really gets to me. During the first wave of Pok√©mania in the late 90s, Pok√©mon was viewed with suspicion by most adults. Now that the¬†first generation of Pok√©maniacs have grown¬†up, even becoming parents¬†ourselves, we see it for what it¬†is: an imaginative, challenging and really rather wholesome series of games that¬†rewards every hour that children devote to it.

Over the three decades since the original Red and Blue (or Green, in Asia) versions of the video game were released in Japan in 1996, Pok√©mon has earned a place among the greats of children‚Äôs fiction. Like Harry Potter, the Famous Five and Narnia, it offers a powerful fantasy of self-determination, set in a world almost totally free of adult supervision. In every game, your mother sends you out into the world with a rucksack and a kiss goodbye; after that, it‚Äôs all on you.

Like The Simpsons, Pok√©mon is a kind of cultural shorthand for the millennial generation. More than Mario, Zelda or any other Nintendo creation, Pok√©mon brings people together. It was designed from the beginning to be a social game, encouraging (and indeed necessitating) that players traded and battled with each other to complete their collection of virtual creatures and train their teams up into super-squads. Today, the internet has entirely normalised the idea of video games as social activities, but in the late 90s this was a novel idea. You can‚Äôt play Pok√©mon without other people: in 1999, that meant huddling in the playground, using a cable to link your Game Boys together; later, in 2016, at the height of the Pok√©mon Go phenomenon, it meant hundreds of people converging improbably at the same park with their phones to catch a Gengar.

Pok√©mon is often thought of as a turn-of-the-century fad, so it might be surprising to learn that it brings in more money now than it ever did at the height of its first wave of popularity. It has become the highest-grossing entertainment franchise of all time: between the TV series, the merchandise, the trading cards, the games and everything else adorned with the adorable faces of Pikachu and pals, the franchise has brought in north of $100bn, more than Star Wars or the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

This global phenomenon has its roots in Machida, a city on the outskirts of Tokyo, where Pok√©mon‚Äôs creator Satoshi Tajiri was born in 1965. Like many Japanese children in the 60s and 70s, little Satoshi collected bugs, becoming such an expert that his elementary school classmates referred to him as Dr Bug. As a teenager a new obsession arrived: video games, then just making their way into Japanese arcades. His enthusiasm was such that he started putting together a monthly zine, with his friend Ken Sugimori, called Game Freak ‚Äì later the name of the video game development company they founded together, which still adorns the title screens of modern Pok√©mon games.

The idea for Pok√©mon began to percolate for Tajiri around 1990. Watching people link their Game Boys together with cables to play Tetris, the hit puzzle game, he envisioned the bugs he‚Äôd collected crawling between the consoles. But it took six long years for this idea to transform into a monochrome world full of 151 collectible critters, in chunky black Game Boy pixels. During this time the developer nearly went bust several times, taking on projects for Nintendo and other game developers to keep afloat; Tajiri regularly went without¬†a salary.

Pok√©mon‚Äôs astronomical success wasn‚Äôt instant, but the result of slow-burning sales over years. When it eventually came out in 1996, Pocket Monsters Red and Green ‚Äì as they were known in Japan ‚Äì were indie underdogs, made by a tiny team with limited technology for the ageing handheld Game Boy console. Nobody expected it to be much of a hit, but the world of Pok√©mon Blue has an unexpected sense of place that transcends their technical limitations. The symbiotic relationship between humans, nature and Pok√©mon permeates every aspect of life, and is often quite touching ‚Äì particularly at in-game locations such as Lavender Town, where the mourning owners of dead Pok√©mon come to honour them at a giant commemorative tower.

But the real marketable genius of Pok√©mon was the fact that the game came in different versions. The reason that Pok√©mon games always come in pairs is that different monsters reside in each cartridge. If you want to collect them all, to complete your Pok√©dex field guide, you need to trade them. Creatures could be sent between cartridges, so friends with different versions of the game could help each other accumulate covetable creatures. With Tetris, the Game Boy‚Äôs link cable¬†was used for competition. Here it¬†was used for connection.

Pok√©mon‚Äôs popularity spread through playground word-of-mouth. By the time it arrived in the US in 1998, and Europe in 1999, it was already a franchise: Pikachu-adorned games, TV shows, toys, films and lunchboxes, were rolled out carefully by marketers with a proven playbook.

Today, Tajiri is a reclusive figure. Almost everything we know about him comes from a single 1999 interview with Time magazine. The tone of Time‚Äôs piece is shockingly dismissive. Declaring the series ‚Äúa pestilential Ponzi scheme‚Äù it describes the ‚Äúdelinquent‚Äù and ‚Äúcriminal‚Äù behaviour of young Pok√©mon fans, and the moral bankruptcy of the whole craze ‚Äì which, it comforts, is likely to peter out soon, like it did for the Power Rangers.

Now that Pok√©mon has become one of the most enduring and successful entertainment properties of all time, this alarmist attitude seems ridiculous. But the scaremongering was very real. Some of this was simply older people failing to understand the¬†new thing that the kids were into. But there was also an alarmingly xenophobic flavour to the moral panic, this scary Japanese thing with its sinister monsters coming over the seas to captivate children. Christian pastors in the US were proclaiming Pikachu to be a demon. There were movements to ban the TV show from airing.

Perhaps understandably, given the disrespectful and, presumably, hurtful tone of that Time interview, and the moral panic that Pok√©mania unwittingly ignited, Satoshi Tajiri has shunned the limelight ever since. Now 60, he remains at Game Freak and is still involved in the creation of each new Pok√©mon game (as of 2025, there are 38 in total), though he reportedly stepped back from day-to-day development in 2012.

July 2016 saw the launch of Pok√©mon Go, a mobile game that quickly became the most popular in US history, with 232 million players across the world. Pok√©mon Go works kind of like magic. With the app open, you walk around your neighbourhood; on your phone screen, you see a map of your real surroundings, with icons showing where Pok√©mon might be found. When you encounter a creature it is superimposed on your real surroundings, a Gengar posing casually in your local park. From there you simply flick a Pok√©ball at the creatures to capture them.

There‚Äôs a unique aspect too to Pok√©mon Go that makes it different to¬†every other video game-related phenomenon I‚Äôve witnessed. Most of¬†the time when we talk about how games can help people through hard times, we talk about escapism: how virtual worlds can be a reprieve from the problems of the real one. But Pok√©mon Go was not so much about¬†escapism as connection, a continuation of the lineage of those first games decades before.

At its height, it connected its players with their local area and the people around them. For a few months, there¬†we were, all looking at our surroundings through a different lens, thinking that there might be a little bit of magic out there in the world, like a¬†bug hiding under a rock.

Dr Bug may not be as involved as before, but the pastoral nature he instilled in Pok√©mon has persisted throughout the last 30 years: the interrelationships between people and Pok√©mon form the touching core of the games, movies and TV shows, and there is even a quasi-environmentalist bent to its stories. This is, after all, a game about evolution and living in harmony with the natural world. There is a resonance with nature that prevents this $100bn franchise from feeling nakedly cynical or exploitative. Pok√©mon‚Äôs story speaks to an important truth about video games: they are a powerful vector for connection between people. Millions are united by these imaginary creatures, born from one boy‚Äôs love of the natural world.

Super Nintendo: How One Japanese Company Helped the World Have Fun by Keza MacDonald is published by Guardian Faber. To support the Guardian, order your copy for ¬£16 at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply.

Arsenal submit updated squad list including 2 new signings
description: Arsenal have submitted their updated Premier League squad list for the remainder of the season, adding in their January academy signings.Photo by Clive Mason/Getty ImagesThe Premier League have confir...
fullText:
The Premier League have confirmed the updated squad lists for the remainder of the 2025/26 season, with Arsenal making few changes to the senior squad list.

With no first-team signings in January, there was no one to add, though perhaps it‚Äôs worth noting that Mikel Merino remains on the list despite his long-term injury. So he‚Äôll be eligible to play if and when he returns to fitness.

On the u21 list, Arsenal have added Evan Mooney and Jaden Dixon after their January moves from St. Mirren and Stoke City. So both will be eligible for Premier League action if called upon.

The good news with Mooney is that he‚Äôs joined before the end of the season in which he turned 18. That means if he spends the next three full seasons with Arsenal he‚Äôll gain homegrown status, something he wasn‚Äôt eligible to get whilst playing in Scotland.

In the meantime, Mooney can be named in the unlimited u21 list, so he‚Äôll never need to use up a non-homegrown senior squad spot.

Back on the squad lists, Ethan Nwaneri has been named on Arsenal‚Äôs u21 list despite going out on loan. As mentioned, there‚Äôs no limit to the number of u21 players you can include, so there‚Äôs no negative consequence to leaving a player on there whilst on loan.

Max Dowman isn‚Äôt included on the list, but he‚Äôs still eligible to play. The u21 list published by the Premier League only includes players on professional contracts and scholarship deals, and Dowman is still currently too young to begin his scholarship.

title: Newcastle manager Howe pleads for Woltemade patience
description: Newcastle manager Eddie Howe has urged fans to be patient with club-record signing Nick Woltemade now the rest of the Premier League is getting to know the German striker's strengths and weaknesses."He is getting to grips with the challenges of the Premier League -- the speed, the intensity and the physicality.
fullText:
Newcastle manager Eddie Howe has urged fans to be patient with club-record signing Nick Woltemade now the rest of the Premier League is getting to know the German striker's strengths and weaknesses.

Woltemade made a fine start to his time in English football following his pre-season arrival from Stuttgart for a fee of ¬£69 million ($94 million) with six goals in his first 11 games for northeast side Newcastle.

But the goals have dried up for the 23-year-old, who has failed to find the back of the net in his last 12 appearances

"He is young, (it's) a new league," Howe said of Woltemade in the build-up to Saturday's match at home to seventh-placed Brentford -- four positions above Newcastle in the table.

"He started so well and I think everybody expected that to continue but I think that is very difficult to do, as much as we wanted that to happen for him.

"He is getting to grips with the challenges of the Premier League -- the speed, the intensity and the physicality.

"And of course teams are getting to know him as well and I think that is the biggest challenge for him. Teams understand his game and what he wants to do so he has to find solutions the other way.

"You have to keep ahead of the other teams so there is work for him to do but I think he has done everything with such a great attitude and great way. That is the biggest thing for me he needs to do to be successful."

Newcastle go into Saturday's match after the League Cup holders' defence of their first major domestic trophy in 70 years ended on Wednesday as Manchester City completed a 5-1 aggregate semi-final win.

That defeat at the Etihad Stadium led to intense social media speculation that the 48-year-old Howe had taken Newcastle as far as he can amid suggestions he could replace Thomas Tuchel as England manager after the World Cup.

Newcastle, however, are just seven points off the top five and still involved in the Champions League -- they face Azerbaijani side Qarabag over two legs for a place in the last 16 later this month -- and the FA Cup.

Howe, responding to all the commentary about his future at St James' Park, said: "That's a surprise to me. I give my best to the football club every single day, to all the players and the staff. I try to be the best version of myself to inspire the team to win games.

"That's my only thought. I don't tend to look too far ahead, but I try to prepare and plan for the club to move forward in every sense. My individual future isn't really relevant.

"Who knows? I don't know my length of time here, I've got no idea. I just try to do my best every day until told differently."

title: England select replacement for Wales after Immanuel Feyi-Waboso injury blow confirmed
description: Feyi-Waboso had been set to start against Wales after missing the entirety of last year‚Äôs campaign due to injury
fullText:
England have been dealt a major injury blow ahead of their Six Nations opener against Wales with Immanuel Feyi-Waboso ruled out.

Feyi-Waboso, who missed the entirety of last year‚Äôs tournament with a shoulder problem, had been set to start on the right wing, but suffered a leg muscle injury in training on Thursday.

The Exeter youngster subsequently underwent a scan on the issue and has been withdrawn from the starting side, with Tom Roebuck installed into the back three.

Roebuck, who enjoyed a breakthrough 2025, had been left out by Steve Borthwick, having not quite been deemed ready to return from his own toe issue when England revealed their side on Monday.

His readiness to replace Feyi-Waboso is nonetheless a boost for Borthwick, with Henry Arundell and Freddie Steward making up the rest of the back three. It will be Roebuck‚Äôs first appearance since starting the wing over the All Blacks in November.

A setback for Feyi-Waboso is nonetheless a real shame for a player in excellent form for Exeter. The 23-year-old wing started all four of England‚Äôs games in November, scoring against Fiji and Argentina to help extend their winning run to 11 matches.

Regular captain Maro Itoje will begin the match against Wales from the bench, with hooker Jamie George skippering the starting side.

title: Argentine star WILL be Liverpool's next signing after Jeremy Jacquet
description: Jeremy Jacquet will only be the beginning of Liverpool's summer arrivals. The Reds have already agreed a deal for him to join the club in July. He's going to be an important addition in a key role whe...
fullText:
Jeremy Jacquet will only be the beginning of Liverpool's summer arrivals.

The Reds have already agreed a deal for him to join the club in July. He's going to be an important addition in a key role where Liverpool are lacking depth.

But Jacquet is not the only arrival expected to walk through the doors at Anfield. Nor is he the only centre-back arrival expected to be coming to Liverpool in the summer.

The reality is that Ibrahima Konate could be on his way out as his contract expires and he's yet to extend. Joe Gomez is the subject of interest from several clubs and almost left to join AC Milan last summer.

With his contract expiring in 2027, it's a possibility Liverpool let him go as well.

This would require another addition at the back, and there is an obvious solution. Someone who can bring both experience and quality at the same time, while also not costing a lot of money for the Reds.

The obvious solution and who we think is going to be Liverpool's next transfer agreement after Jacquet is Marcos Senesi.

His contract expires in the summer, meaning he will be a free agent. He already has a lot of experience in the Premier League and he's also versatile, capable of playing in a number of different roles across the back four.

Most importantly, Arne Slot knows him well. Senesi worked together with him at Feyenoord during the 2021/22 season before he departed the Dutch side.

Given Liverpool are going to have two very young centre-backs in Jacquet and Giovanni Leoni, bringing in Senesi makes a lot of sense.

He'll be 29-years-old by the time the summer comes rolling around. The Argentine is not someone Liverpool would normally look at. The club always has a long-term vision.

But sometimes you have to break your policy. James Milner, Wataru Endo and others are an example of this.

When you're trying to build squad depth, having a player like Senesi, who is older and more trusted with a lot of experience under his belt is important.

Especially, if you're going to lose Konate and Gomez.

It's also important to mention that Senesi is an underrated player. He's been a key pillar for Bournemouth over the last couple of years and has often been their unsung hero.

While Dean Huijsen and Ilyia Zabarnyi got most of the praise last season, Senesi more than played his part in a successful season for the Cherries.

So, this is a deal that just makes sense on so many levels. After Jacquet, we expect Senesi will be the next signing to walk through the doors at the AXA training centre.

title: Ex-Juventus midfielder: Three players ‚Äòadding nothing‚Äô ahead of ‚Äòterrible month‚Äô
description: Former Juventus midfielder Alessio Tacchinardi criticises Teun Koopmeiners, Lois Openda and Edon Zhegrova following the Old Lady‚Äôs Coppa Italia exit: ‚ÄòThey add nothing, and Juve have a terrible mo...
fullText:
Former Juventus midfielder Alessio Tacchinardi criticises Teun Koopmeiners, Lois Openda and Edon Zhegrova following the Old Lady‚Äôs Coppa Italia exit: ‚ÄòThey add nothing, and Juve have a terrible month ahead.‚Äô

Juventus faceda¬† Coppa Italia exit on Thursday, losing 3-0 against Atalanta in Bergamo.

Former Juventus midfielder Tacchinardi examined the game during SportMediaset‚Äôs post-match show, blaming the Old Lady‚Äôs reserves and focusing particularly on three players.

EPA PHOTO EFE/MIGUEL RIOPA/MK-hh

‚ÄúThe result was too harsh for Juve, because they put in a very good performance,‚Äù Tacchinardi said via Tuttosport.

‚ÄúThey created a lot before the penalty, which, for me, was nonexistent. They are playing great football, but paid a high price because they were unable to finalise their attacks. After all, who wins is right.‚Äù

Juventus coach Luciano Spalletti argued after the match that his players made the wrong decisions in the key moments of the game, contrary to Atalanta, who were clinical and converted most of their chances.

Jonathan David started the match in Bergamo last night, but failed to find the net. The Canada striker has been in good form in recent weeks, scoring four times in his last five Serie A appearances.

‚ÄúI think Juventus wanted a striker with different characteristics because he wants the ball inside the box and he fights, but it‚Äôs not enough, and he‚Äôs still shy up there,‚Äù Tacchinardi said.

TURIN, ITALY ‚Äì DECEMBER 02: Teun Koopmeiners of Juventus controls the ball while under pressure from Oier Zarraga of Udinese Calcio during the Serie C match between Ternana Calcio and Juventus Next Gen at Allianz Stadium on December 02, 2025 in Turin, Italy. (Photo by Valerio Pennicino/Getty Images)

‚ÄúJuventus have many tough games coming up, and David and Openda are not increasing their level. I see a player who puts in commitment, but is struggling. Juventus‚Äô reserves are struggling, but Spalletti can‚Äôt use only 11 players and needs everyone to improve. Koopmeiners, Openda and Zhegrova are adding nothing, but Spalletti needs them because he has a terrible month ahead.‚Äù

The Serie A giants will host Lazio in their next Serie A match on Sunday before visiting Inter the following week.

Before the end of February, they‚Äôll also meet Galatasaray twice in the Champions League play-off and host Como in Serie A.

Even March won‚Äôt start softly as their first game next month will be away at Roma.

title: Jack Doohan will like what Ayao Komatsu had to say about Esteban Ocon as he pushes for an F1 return
description: After just six races into the 2025 F1 season, Jack Doohan was replaced by Franco Colapinto at Alpine and started to fade from the scene soon after. Colapinto‚Äôs pointless debut year did little to shift Alpine‚Äôs view, and by January, they had cut ties altogether so Doohan could look elsewhere.
fullText:
After just six races into the 2025 F1 season, Jack Doohan was replaced by Franco Colapinto at Alpine and started to fade from the scene soon after.

Colapinto‚Äôs pointless debut year did little to shift Alpine‚Äôs view, and by January, they had cut ties altogether so Doohan could look elsewhere.

He was linked with a move to Super Formula, but that didn‚Äôt pan out either. Three crashes at the same Suzuka corner during testing didn‚Äôt help his cause.

The 23-year-old has now been named Haas reserve driver for 2026, joining Ryo Hirakawa in the role. The target is clear: a path back onto the F1 grid. Recent remarks from team principal Ayao Komatsu about Esteban Ocon might provide exactly the kind of motivation Doohan needs to seize that chance.

Speaking to Motorsport Italia about Ocon‚Äôs first season with the team after his move from Alpine, Komatsu didn‚Äôt shy away from sharing some critical thoughts.

‚ÄúIf you look purely at the sporting result, without going into the details, certainly no one is satisfied with Esteban‚Äôs sporting result last year,‚Äù Komatsu said.

‚ÄúHe was the teammate of a rookie. Yes, an extraordinary rookie, but he still has 10 years of F1 behind him. He‚Äôs a race winner, he‚Äôs been on the podium. So we expected more from him.‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt all on Ocon though. The team boss admitted there were issues on their side as well.

‚ÄúAnd obviously it‚Äôs not entirely his fault, it‚Äôs a 50-50 situation. Sometimes it‚Äôs the team: we weren‚Äôt able to give him a car he felt comfortable with, especially in qualifying.‚Äù

The problems seemed to hit harder at certain tracks than others. Komatsu pointed to Baku as a clear example.

Ollie Bearman happens to be one of Haas‚Äô most successful drivers ever and won seven races over two seasons before joining Red Bull for 2026 where he continued his form by winning another three races.

But despite that context for Ocon, things are never simple in Formula 1 and there are always multiple reasons why things go wrong between both driver and team.

Ocon ended the 2025 F1 drivers‚Äô championship in 15th place, three points and two spots behind rookie teammate Oliver Bearman.

It‚Äôs not a great look, especially as he was the only experienced driver to finish behind a rookie teammate over a full season, with Liam Lawson‚Äôs short stint at Red Bull being the only exception.

Even more concerning was his form towards the end of the year. Ocon scored points in just five of the final 13 races, and if that trend continues into next season, Haas might start looking seriously at Jack Doohan as an alternative.

Ocon also expressed frustration with his car during an interview in Abu Dhabi. He said: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of instability. I feel like I don‚Äôt know how to drive anymore, like I can‚Äôt put a lap together. It‚Äôs been unmanageable for many races.‚Äù

He continued: ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt solve the problems, and the car doesn‚Äôt suit my driving style, so‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre just slow. We‚Äôre very, very far from where we should be.‚Äù

This could be a make-or-break season for Ocon, with Komatsu potentially already considering Doohan as his successor if things don‚Äôt improve quickly.

title: Enzo Maresca explains Chelsea injury crisis to Liam Rosenior
description: Chelsea and Enzo Maresca parted ways after the manager reportedly clashed with club officials over how injuries were being managed. The ownership group, led by Todd Boehly, had already built a reputation for this sort of thing.
fullText:
Chelsea and Enzo Maresca parted ways after the manager reportedly clashed with club officials over how injuries were being managed.

The ownership group, led by Todd Boehly, had already built a reputation for this sort of thing. One example came before Thomas Tuchel was sacked when he was denied entry into the dressing room.

As for Maresca, despite winning two trophies in his previous campaign, it did not end much better. Reports pointed to ongoing disagreements over player injuries and medical decisions as the main cause.

There were even suggestions that a staff member was assigned to oversee how returning players were being reintroduced into matches.

The constant back-and-forth eventually led to the two sides splitting up.

And the situation still seems to be troubling Maresca.

Maresca, speaking at a recent awards event, hinted that he plans to remain in England.

While at the same event, he also addressed some recent FIFA findings regarding injuries at Chelsea (per FCInter1908).

‚ÄúWhat do I think about the fact that we play too much? Either you adapt or you don‚Äôt train or you don‚Äôt play a player. The reality is that there are more and more games: with Chelsea playing in the Club World Cup we didn‚Äôt take holidays, retirement, everything is a consequence,‚Äù the Italian manager said.

‚ÄúA few days ago a FIFA study came out that indicated Chelsea and PSG as the teams with the most injuries, coincidentally the finalists of the World Cup. In short, either you adapt or you struggle.‚Äù

Maresca‚Äôs concerns about player fatigue appear to be supported by recent data. He pointed to their run to the 2025 Club World Cup final as having a clear impact on squad fitness.

The Howden Men‚Äôs European Football Injury Index tracked 23 injuries for Chelsea between June and October 2025, representing a 44% rise from the previous season.

Maresca often spoke about how fixture congestion was affecting his team, including an occasion when he was without seven or eight players for a match against Liverpool.

The recent addition of Jamie Gittens to an already extensive list brings everything into clearer focus.

title: Crisis-hit Welsh rugby aiming to halt decline
description: Travelling to Twickenham has provided Welsh fans with some magic memories over the years, but the landscape is different in 2026.
fullText:
Travelling to Twickenham to face England has provided Welsh fans with some magic memories over the years.

JPR Williams rampaging through the Red Rose defence, Adrian Hadley gliding over, Scott Williams' rip and rampage to Triple Crown glory and Gareth Davies and Dan Biggar breaking English hearts in their own World Cup in 2015.

But in 2026, the landscape looks very different.

There is continued discontent in Welsh rugby with Steve Tandy's side arriving in south-west London this weekend with faint hope of a positive result from fans, but little expectation from most observers.

This week's build-up to the Six Nations opener has been a sideshow to Welsh rugby's ongoing, deep-rooted crisis. The latest issue is the potential disappearance from professional rugby of Ospreys.

Welsh rugby has given the nation much delight in the past, with famous victories and Grand Slam memories, but for many the life is now slowly being sucked out of the game in Wales.

So how has a nation that topped the world rankings less than seven years ago fallen so far, so quickly?

England v Wales - your guide to the Six Nations date

Six Nations preview & BBC pundit predictions

What impact might 'unprecedented' Six Nations schedule have?

Ospreys have previously been the saviour of Welsh rugby at Twickenham.

Eighteen years ago, Wales travelled to face England in a Six Nations opener which was also Warren Gatland's first game in charge.

The New Zealander had spent less than two weeks with his new squad and famously went for familiarity, making the historic decision to start 13 Ospreys.

Cardiff flanker Martyn Williams and Scarlets wing Mark Jones, the current Ospreys head coach, were the exceptions.

The policy worked as Wales won 26-19 on their way to a Grand Slam. They were also Grand Slam winners in 2012 and 2019, with a further Six Nations title in 2013 and two World Cup semi-finals during that period.

Ospreys provided a large number of Gatland's players during his first stint in charge, as they became the most successful side since the inception of regional rugby 23 years ago, claiming four league titles between 2003 and 2012.

They produced Shane Williams, who won World Rugby's player of the year in 2008, while Ospreys' record appearance holder Alun Wyn Jones is also the world's most-capped international.

That is before you mention former star players such as Gavin Henson, Mike Phillips, Tommy Bowe, James Hook, Justin Marshall, Jerry Collins, Justin Tipuric, Adam Jones and Ryan Jones.

There are eight Ospreys players in the current squad and four involved against England this weekend, while Tandy himself is a former player and coach at the region.

But a rich recent history is now being threatened.

Pollock out to ruffle Six Nations feathers

Wales' Prem talent has England 'scratching heads'

Man for man we're ready to stand up - Macleod

Alun Wyn Jones was part of the Twickenham triumphs of 2008, 2012 and 2015 and was Wales' captain when they were top of the world.

This week he found himself sitting in a council meeting in Swansea - alongside current and former players - discussing whether Ospreys would still be a top-tier side after next year.

The news that Ospreys owners Y11 Sport and Media have been named as the preferred bidder by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) to buy rivals Cardiff, who went into administration in 2025, sent shockwaves through Welsh rugby.

With the WRU committed to cutting a men's professional side, Ospreys' existence is in doubt.

The region covers proud rugby areas like Swansea, Neath, Aberavon, Maesteg and Bridgend, and there has been widespread criticism of the WRU's plans from current players, coaches and staff, who say they have been left in the dark.

There has been political condemnation, petitions and protests from supporters and former players, public meetings and threats of legal action from Swansea Council.

As a result the proposed restructure of the Welsh game has attracted the most headlines in a troubled Six Nations build-up, tied in with a fascination about why Welsh rugby has fallen into the abyss.

English, French and Irish journalists and broadcasters have been travelling to Wales to try to establish the reasons for the Welsh game being in such a state.

In previous years, the prospects for a Six Nations opener against England at Twickenham, now called the Allianz Stadium, would have filled airwaves and column inches.

On this occasion, the match has not been mentioned in Wales as much as the off-the-field issues affecting Welsh rugby.

The belief in a huge gulf between the rivals has led to alarmingly few giving Tandy's team a hope against an England side who embarrassed Wales 10 months ago with a 10-try, 68-14 demolition victory in Cardiff.

'No bigger game' - Rees-Zammit on England v Wales rivalry

Rees-Zammit at full-back for Wales against England

Wales are 'damaged', but dangerous - Genge

The need for change is evident even if people vehemently disagree on how it should be achieved, with no fans wanting to lose their team.

Wales topped the world rankings briefly in 2019 and won the Six Nations title two years later.

It has been an alarming decline since, except for a run to the 2023 World Cup quarter-finals.

The slump is the result of the almost collective retirement of a golden generation of players.

The WRU lack of investment in the professional sides in recent years and the pathway intended to develop the next raft of stars has also contributed.

Wales men have lost 21 out of their past 23 internationals, with their only victories coming against Japan.

The various defeats included an unprecedented 18-match Test losing sequence and record home losses against England, Argentina and South Africa.

Wales have not won a Six Nations match since March 2023, when they beat Italy in Rome, with a record of 11 successive defeats resulting in two winless tournaments and consecutive Wooden Spoons.

Wales have not won a home Six Nations game since defeating Scotland in February 2022.

It is the Principality Stadium stage where Wales' plight could be most visible during the next six weeks. Wales have home matches against France, Scotland and Italy, with ticket sales slow.

More than 50% of Welsh rugby's turnover comes from revenue from Wales men's internationals.

Fans walking away could hit the Welsh game in the pocket. But walking away they are and rugby is no longer the be-all and end-all in Welsh sport.

Last month, a parliamentary committee looking into the state of Welsh rugby was told by WRU chair Richard Collier-Keywood that the body retains the support of the fans.

That raised more than a few eyebrows, while Collier-Keywood is facing the prospect of a vote of no-confidence at a potential extraordinary general meeting with current faith and trust in the governing body questionable.

The union says it is trying to transform the struggling Welsh game by making hard decisions, including the loss of a professional side.

It argues two critical elements needed to sustain four strong teams are in short supply: enough money and quality players.

There are those who doubt the rationale behind losing a team and many who believe the union lacks the capability and knowledge to oversee the huge project.

The WRU's continued silence is also a problem, with no interviews given for the last few months by the hierarchy.

There have only been statements, prompting accusations of little transparency or clarity levelled at the governing body.

The continued controversies are not exactly setting up Wales' players to succeed.

Swansea Council say they 'were told Ospreys wouldn't exist'

Ospreys fans ramp up protest against WRU and Y11

WRU accused of 'malicious cultural vandalism'

Former Wales and British and Irish Lions centre Jamie Roberts is one of the 12 WRU board members.

He is one of the nation's most decorated players in the professional era but is now known for his union role.

So Roberts was part of the board that voted for the culling of one region and for Ospreys' owners to take over Cardiff, decisions which could contribute to ending Ospreys' time as a professional side.

Ospreys fans made their feelings known at a peaceful, but forceful, protest before last week's derby against Dragons in Bridgend, where Roberts was working as a television pundit and was booed by home supporters.

The move prompted one Welsh commentator to remark: "Sport is meant to be fun. Welsh rugby is just so toxic."

You cannot accuse Welsh rugby of being boring, but it does not bring much enjoyment right now.

Whether that can start to change this weekend, in Tandy's first Six Nations game in charge as Wales aim to build on some positive aspects of the previous autumn, remains to be seen.

Tandy has experienced a baptism of fire since starting as he aims to rekindle a struggling side, while navigating off-the-field problems that are not of his making.

If he could somehow deliver a win over England and provide one of the biggest upsets in Welsh rugby history - what a catalyst that could be.

The same problems would remain, but that glimmer of hope would return. How Welsh rugby needs it.

title: Kings' Artemi Panarin has a mascot problem with jersey number 72
description: A classic dispute on the ice.
fullText:
Kings' Artemi Panarin has a mascot problem with jersey number 72 originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Artemi Panarin got the contract extension he was seeking upon his trade to the Los Angeles Kings from the New York Rangers.

But the jersey number he wants? That's complicated.

Panarin wants to wear 72, which is the number he wore in Chicago.

It's already taken with the Kings, though... by the mascot!

The mascot's name is Bailey. He's named for the late scout, Garnet 'Ace' Bailey.

Supposedly, Bailey wears 72 to represent the ideal or average temperature in Los Angeles.

The team is leaning in to the dispute:

Panarin, I‚Äôm listening‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/5q7NuCkotM

‚Äî Bailey LA Kings (@BaileyLAKings) February 6, 2026

MORE:¬†How Connor McDavid is to the Oilers what Josh Allen is to the Bills

Clearly, the number a mascot wears doesn't actually determine what Panarin can or can't do. The mascot isn't on the official roster or on the ice during games, so there's no true logistical issue for the hockey team.

It does make sense for the Kings to at least have some fun with this. They could do a new number reveal for Bailey, if they want, and make a whole promotional deal about it.

It seems highly unlikely that Panarin wouldn't get the number he wants just because of a mascot.

Either way, the Kings have some time to work through this. With the Olympic break now on hand, they can goof around on this front for a couple weeks before having to unveil Panarin on the ice.

title: Girona B will seek the three points at Narc√≠s Sala.
description: The reserve team of Girona FC travels to the Catalan capital with the aim of earning points in a very demanding visit to Narc√≠s Sala, where UE Sant Andreu is always one of the toughest opponents in t...
fullText:
The reserve team of Girona FC travels to the Catalan capital with the aim of earning points in a very demanding visit to Narc√≠s Sala, where UE Sant Andreu is always one of the toughest opponents in the Segona RFEF.

The Girona B arrives after losing three points in the last play of the match against Reus. The visit to Sant Andreu comes at a crucial moment in the season, where every point away from home is golden to aim for a higher position in the standings and to move away from the relegation zone.

For their part, Sant Andreu arrives as one of the favorites to achieve promotion, strong at home and accustomed to imposing their rhythm in decisive matches. Additionally, they will have the support of their fans, who always make matches difficult for opposing teams.

The new signing, Javi Gonz√°lez, who scored a goal on his debut, stated:

‚ÄòWe will try to earn the three points, we know it will be very difficult, but we will work all week to fight for it.‚Äô

In the last encounter between the two teams, it was the first leg match, where the Girona team won 2-1 in Vidreres against the quadribarrat team and will try to repeat it this Sunday at 6:00 PM. The match can be followed on Esport3 and the Academy's social media channels.

title: Eddie Howe quizzed on his Newcastle future after Carabao Cup defeat
description: Eddie Howe says he is surprised by talk of him leaving Newcastle.Following Newcastle United‚Äôs Carabao Cup exit as they lost 5-1 on aggregate to Manchester City, there has been speculation that he ma...
fullText:
Eddie Howe says he is surprised by talk of him leaving Newcastle.

Following Newcastle United‚Äôs Carabao Cup exit as they lost 5-1 on aggregate to Manchester City, there has been speculation that he may leave the club at the end of the season.

Asked about the comments ahead of Newcastle‚Äôs clash against Brentford, Howe shut down the talk of an exit.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a surprise to me. I give my best to the football club every single day, to all the players and the staff,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI try to be the best version of myself to inspire the team to win games. That‚Äôs my only thought.‚Äù

He added: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt tend to look too far ahead, but I try to prepare and plan for the club to move forward in every sense. My individual future isn‚Äôt really relevant.

‚ÄúWho knows? I don‚Äôt know my length of time here, I‚Äôve got no idea. I just try to do my best every day until told differently,‚Äù he concluded.

Howe‚Äôs side are now four games without a win, having lost to Liverpool at Anfield in between their two-legged defeat at the hands of City, as well as a loss to Aston Villa at the end of January.

Newcastle have dropped down to 11th in the table, but a win could see them leapfrog Brentford in seventh. They have struggled with injuries this season, and will be without Anthony Gordon at St James‚Äô Park as the winger came off injured in the semi-final second leg.

title: Olympics opening ceremony welcomes Winter Games back to the Alps
description: After a 20 years, the Winter Olympics are returning to the Alps and the 2026 edition of the Games will officially start with the opening ceremony on Friday evening. For the first time, there are two host cities: Italy's financial and fashion capital Milan and Cortina d'Ampezzo.
fullText:
After a 20 years, the Winter Olympics are returning to the Alps and the 2026 edition of the Games will officially start with the opening ceremony on Friday evening.

For the first time, there are two host cities: Italy's financial and fashion capital Milan and Cortina d'Ampezzo. The ski resort in the Dolomites was previously the host in 1956.

The competitions will take place in seven different locations in northern Italy as 2,900 athletes will compete for gold, silver, and bronze medals until February 22.

The main opening ceremony will begin at 8 pm (1900 GMT) in Milan's San Siro stadium. Italian President Sergio Mattarella will officially open the 25th Winter Games with a speech.

The musical program will feature many prominent figures, such as pop star Mariah Carey and Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli.

The traditional athlete parade will also take place in Cortina d'Ampezzo, Predazzo, and Livigno.

Also for the first time, there's going to be two Olympic cauldrons: one at the Arco della Pace in Milan and another at Piazza Dibona in Cortina.

It's still unknown who will light them up, but according to media reports Olympic alpine skiing champions Alberto Tomba and Deborah Caompagnoni will take the prestigious task.

Several prominent political figures will be in attendance. More than 50 heads of state and government are expected to be at the San Siro.

US President Donald Trump won't attend the ceremony, but US Vice President JD Vance landed in Milan on Thursday. Germany will be represented by President Frank-Walter Steinmeier.

The opening ceremony, as well as the entire Games, will take place under tight security amid fears of attacks and sabotage. More than 6,000 security personnel will be on duty during the event.

title: Italian team believes Passler is innocent after positive doping
description: The Italian biathlon team believes in Rebecca Passler's innocence after her positive doping test ahead of the 2026 Olympics, which open later on Friday. "We stand behind Rebecca and are convinced that she's innocent and that everything will be cleared up," sporting director Klaus H√∂llrigl told broadcaster Rai.
fullText:
The Italian biathlon team believes in Rebecca Passler's innocence after her positive doping test ahead of the 2026 Olympics, which open later on Friday.

"We stand behind Rebecca and are convinced that she's innocent and that everything will be cleared up," sporting director Klaus H√∂llrigl told broadcaster Rai.

The entire team is convinced that it was a misunderstanding, he added.

Passler tested positive for the banned substance letrozole and is provisionally suspended on Monday. She was caught in an out of competition test.

"We sought advice from psychologists on how best to deal with the situation. Because, of course, the news hit the whole team hard," H√∂llrigl said.

Passler is doing well under the circumstances, he added.

"Rebecca is a strong woman, she will surely get over it in time. Rebecca is an important part of our team."

Passler, 24, is from Anterselva, where the Olympic biathlon events will take place. The former junior world champion has competed in the World Cup since 2021 and has two relay podium finishes.

She was part of a five-person women's team, but for now she won't be replaced.

title: NBA MVP odds as of February 6, 2026
description: The NBA MVP race is beginning to take real shape, with clear frontrunners separating themselves as the season moves past its midpoint. Betting odds now reflect not just raw statistics, but team success, narrative momentum, and nightly impact across the‚Ä¶
fullText:
The NBA MVP race is beginning to take real shape, with clear frontrunners separating themselves as the season moves past its midpoint. Betting odds now reflect not just raw statistics, but team success, narrative momentum, and nightly impact across the league. From established superstars to rising faces driving unexpected contenders, the MVP conversation is deeper than it first appears.

Shai Gilgeous-Alexander sits comfortably atop the MVP futures market after back-to-back elite seasons and leading Oklahoma City to one of the league‚Äôs best records. His scoring prowess and all-around impact have triggered MVP buzz, and he‚Äôs continued to show growth as a facilitator and defender. The narrative around SGA as a legitimate back-to-back MVP contender has only strengthened as the Thunder emerge as a true title contender. Voters often reward both team success and statistical dominance, and he delivers on both fronts.

Nikola Jokiƒá remains one of the most uniquely dominant players in NBA history ‚Äî a perennial MVP presence with a rare combination of scoring, playmaking and rebounding for a center. Even with Denver not topping the standings, his efficiency and court vision keep him squarely in the award conversation. Jokic‚Äôs ability to influence winning in so many statistical areas makes him irresistible to a certain slice of voters. His experience and broad skill set mean he can surge late if Nuggets‚Äô team performance improves.

Luka Donƒçiƒá continues his MVP-caliber rise in Los Angeles, producing gaudy scoring, assist and rebound numbers night after night. His March and April performances often define MVP narratives, and if he carries the Lakers deep into the standings, his odds will tighten. Donƒçiƒá‚Äôs marketability and high-usage role give him a real story appeal with voters ‚Äî a flashy star leading an iconic franchise. Sustained excellence and healthy availability position him as the most compelling challenger behind the favorites.

Cade Cunningham has steadily climbed MVP boards by turning Detroit into an unexpectedly strong team in the East. His balance of scoring, playmaking, and defensive improvement has transformed the Pistons into a top-tier squad. While Pistons‚Äô overall reputation may lag behind some contenders, Cunningham‚Äôs leadership is undeniable. Should Detroit continue exceeding expectations, he stands to benefit significantly in MVP voting.

Jaylen Brown‚Äôs MVP case hinges on Boston‚Äôs success and consistency as a top East seed while carrying increased offensive responsibility. A gifted two-way wing, Brown‚Äôs metrics often reflect efficient scoring and defensive impact. If he sustains high usage with balanced efficiency and Celtics stay elite, his narrative will improve. Voters may reward his often underappreciated contributions if Brown becomes the clear focal point of a championship-level team.

Tyrese Maxey‚Äôs odds are long primarily due to team context ‚Äî a 76ers squad that has struggled for consistency ‚Äî but his individual production has been impressive. Known for his scoring outbursts and clutch shooting, Maxey can light up the stat sheet any night. For MVP consideration, sustained team success is critical, which currently limits his market position. Still, as a budding star, Maxey‚Äôs profile could rise if Philly shifts toward a more impactful regular season.

Anthony Edwards has the raw star talent to climb MVP boards ‚Äî elite scoring, athleticism and flair for big moments ‚Äî but his MVP odds reflect team inconsistencies and limited playoff expectations. If Minnesota makes a leap into the top echelon of the West, his value proposition improves dramatically. Edwards‚Äô personality and highlight-level scoring give him a narrative edge, but MVP voters typically balance that with team success. Watch for late-season surges to flip his standing.

Jalen Brunson‚Äôs MVP floor rests more on his excellence than his current team‚Äôs record position ‚Äî the Knicks‚Äô defensive identity doesn‚Äôt always translate to traditional MVP narratives. As a steady veteran leader with efficient scoring and playmaking, Brunson ticks many boxes, though sustaining this into MVP consideration requires Knicks to inch into elite territory. His narrative hinges on exceeding expectations with a gritty, team-first profile.

Donovan Mitchell‚Äôs MVP odds reflect Cavs‚Äô standing as competitive but not among the league‚Äôs elite, limiting his case despite strong perimeter scoring. Known for explosive offense, Mitchell still needs a breakout franchise season to garner MVP traction. If Cleveland shocks top franchises and Mitchell pushes them, his narrative could shift. Right now, he represents a long-shot with scoring appeal but modest MVP viability.

Kawhi Leonard‚Äôs MVP odds are more symbolic than realistic ‚Äî injuries and limited availability make sustained MVP candidacy unlikely. When healthy, he‚Äôs a two-time Finals MVP and perennial All-Star with elite two-way impact. However, MVP awards rarely go to players with restricted games, especially given Clippers‚Äô middling results. Leonard‚Äôs narrative is better suited to playoff impact than regular-season hardware.

While the odds suggest a favorite, the MVP race is far from settled, especially with months of high-leverage basketball still ahead. Late-season surges, injuries, and shifts in the standings can dramatically reshape voter perception. As history has shown, the final stretch often decides who turns elite production into league-wide recognition.

The post NBA MVP odds as of February 6, 2026 appeared first on The Big Lead.

title: Bayern Munich Interested In Inter Milan & Germany Defender: The Situation
description: Bayern Munich are reportedly keeping a close eye on Inter Milan defender Yann Aurel Bisseck as they begin shaping their future plans at the back.According to reports from German outlet Sport1, via FCI...
fullText:
Bayern Munich are reportedly keeping a close eye on Inter Milan defender Yann Aurel Bisseck as they begin shaping their future plans at the back.

According to reports from German outlet Sport1, via FCInterNews, the Bavarian giants have added Bisseck to their shortlist of potential defensive reinforcements.

At this stage, however, there have been no direct contacts with either the player or Inter, with Bayern still in the monitoring phase as they evaluate multiple profiles.

The Bundesliga champions are exploring centre-back options despite receiving a positive signal from Dayot Upamecano over a contract renewal.

MILAN, ITALY ‚Äì NOVEMBER 09: Yann Aurel Bisseck of FC Internazionale looks on during the Serie A match between FC Internazionale and SS Lazio at Giuseppe Meazza Stadium on November 09, 2025 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

With that situation moving in the right direction, Bayern are still keen to strengthen and refresh their defensive department, particularly with an eye on the long term.

Bisseck‚Äôs name has emerged alongside another highly rated youngster, Luka Vuskovic. The 18-year-old is currently at Hamburg on loan from Tottenham Hotspur and is considered one of the most promising defensive talents in Europe.

For Bayern, this is very much a phase of information gathering rather than active negotiation. For Inter, meanwhile, interest from one of Europe‚Äôs biggest clubs underlines Bisseck‚Äôs growing reputation after establishing himself as a reliable option in Simone Inzaghi‚Äôs defensive rotations.

Whether Bayern‚Äôs interest develops into something more concrete will likely depend on how their internal renewal talks and summer priorities evolve in the coming months.

title: Sheffield United confirm Deadline Day loan additions of O‚ÄôLeary, Guyett and Hill
description: Sheffield United have announced the loan signings of Lia O‚ÄôLeary, Shauna Guyatt and Scarlett Hill.The Blades completed the deals ahead of the closure of the winter transfer window on Tuesday evening...
fullText:
The Blades completed the deals ahead of the closure of the winter transfer window on Tuesday evening.

Winger O‚ÄôLeary joins Sheffield United on loan from Bristol City until the end of the season. The youngster joined Bristol City from SSE Airtricity League Women‚Äôs Premier Division club Shamrock Rovers a year ago. She has made 10 appearances for The Robins so far, although minutes have been hard to come by this season.

Midfielder Guyatt will also spend the remainder of the season on loan at Sheffield United from Ipswich Town. Guyatt is in her second season with The Tractor Girls. She won the FA Women‚Äôs National League Southern Premier Division title with the Suffolk club last season.

Teenage defender Hill has also joined The Blades on loan until the summer. The 18-year-old arrives in South Yorkshire from Manchester United. Hill has found herself on the fringes of the Manchester United squad after coming through the club‚Äôs academy system.

Sheffield United are next in action this evening when they travel to Sunderland in Barclays WSL2. The Blades will be looking to build on some competitive performances in the early weeks of 2026.

title: Inside the Milan Olympic Village: Real beds, free tech and other athlete perks
description: The Olympic Village in Milan offers plenty of perks and amenities for athletes, including free food, stress plants and beds that are not made of cardboard.
fullText:
The Olympic Village rises above the security fences that surround it, a collection of structures both temporary and permanent where the athletes will reside over the next two-plus weeks at the Milan-Cortina Games.

Out on the sidewalk and behind barriers, lookie-loos crane their necks for a peek at the competitors, while pin traders mill through the churning crowd in hopes of making a souvenir swap.

But what‚Äôs it like inside the Village, where the medal hopefuls work out, mingle and relax before some of the biggest moments of their young lives?

‚ÄúThe best part is the food,‚Äù said Micah Moore, bobsledder from Trinidad and Tobago, echoing what people have said for centuries about Italy. ‚ÄúNutrition is so important. And everything you see is free.‚Äù

Ah, yes, gratis. That‚Äôs a common theme in the Olympic Village, where corporate sponsors of the Games have gotten creative with their free goods and services ‚Äî and swag bags ‚Äî for the athletes.

There are multiple rooms devoted to gaming, with virtual-reality glasses over here, and ‚ÄúCall of Duty‚Äù over there, and overstuffed chairs and couches everywhere. There are the typical role-playing video games, along with virtual tennis and dirtbike riding, but conspicuously absent are any winter sports. Organizers explain the rooms are meant to be an escape from that all-encompassing world.

Speaking of escapes, Corona Cero ‚Äî the non-alcoholic version of that beer ‚Äî has constructed a pair of round, glass-roofed wooden structures that feel like part-ski lodge, part-yurt and are filled with plants and comfortable seats and soft music where the athletes can kick back with a chilled beverage. (It has been mild weather for a Milan winter.)

There are rolled-up yoga mats in the corner, and a chalkboard outside lists times for a breathwork class with Sarah, a soundbath session with Guilia, and restorative yoga and meditation in the afternoon.

Not far away, and made of similar wood, is a wagon labeled the Cero (‚Äúzero‚Äù) Stress Plant Shop. There, an athlete can adopt a houseplant for the duration of his or her stay, nurturing it for a couple weeks before it‚Äôs donated to a local charity, perhaps for auction. The competitor is given a pack of seeds upon departure to grow the same plant at home.

Four-time Olympian Madison Chock said she was ‚Äúpleasantly surprised‚Äù the competitors could foster plants. She said the plant that she shares with husband/ice dance partner Evan Bates is named ‚ÄúStenry,‚Äù a combination of their dogs‚Äô names, Stella and Henry. She said the plant is thriving, although she doesn‚Äôt know the variety, only that it‚Äôs dangly and has leaves that cascade down like a waterfall.

Of course, sitting around and watching plants grow can get a little dull. This week, the arriving athletes seemed more interested in getting accustomed to their free Samsung phones and using their own hand gestures to direct a robotic hand behind glass to pick up a plastic ball encasing a mystery Olympic pin. The AI demonstration by Alibaba Cloud is a futuristic version of those arcade games where you maneuver a metal claw to grab a stuffed animal.

The Olympics is filled with young, beautiful athletes, so it‚Äôs no wonder two of the more popular pop-ups in the Village provide skin and haircare products and services. KIKO Milano has cosmetic stations where athletes can schedule makeup appointments ‚Äî very popular before the Opening Ceremonies ‚Äî and Procter & Gamble has built a ‚ÄúChampions Clubhouse‚Äù for scalp massages, hair washing and styling, along with barbers for personalized shaving and beard care.

There are P&G swag bags of course ‚Äî some athletes arrived without any toiletries ‚Äî and KIKO engraves complimentary tubes of lipstick with the names of competitors.

Coca-Cola takes that engraving process a step further with a machine that snaps a photo of the user, then embosses that picture onto the iconic red can of soda.

Beyond the keepsakes, the Olympic organizers have gotten an essential right in the Village. Gone are the flimsy cardboard bedframes of the Tokyo Olympics in 2021, held during the coronavirus pandemic.

There was speculation at the time that those beds were designed to discourage casual sex among the competitors because the frames would break apart at the slightest provocation. Organizers brushed off those rumors, heralding the beds as sturdy and eco-friendly.

Regardless, when she arrived at this year‚Äôs Olympic Village, Britain figure skater Phebe Bekker posted a Tik-Tok video from her room that answered a popular question among the athletes, many of whom found the cardboard beds uncomfortable.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking good,‚Äù she said, knocking on her wooden bedframe and testing the mattress. ‚ÄúHeard it here first, there are no cardboard beds, as far as I know.‚Äù

Just like the slogan of that popular soft drink. It‚Äôs the real thing.

Staff writer Thuc Nhi Nguyen contributed to this report.

Get the best, most interesting and strangest stories of the day from the L.A. sports scene and beyond from our newsletter The Sports Report.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Five Italy internationals trying to impress for 2026 World Cup after January transfers
description: Several Italy internationals moved clubs during the January transfer window, but which ones will be hoping to earn more regular minutes ahead of a potential World Cup campaign in the summer of 2026?It...
fullText:
Several Italy internationals moved clubs during the January transfer window, but which ones will be hoping to earn more regular minutes ahead of a potential World Cup campaign in the summer of 2026?

BERGAMO, ITALY ‚Äì JANUARY 25: Giacomo Raspdori of Atalanta celebrates scoring his team‚Äôs third goal with teammate Nikola Krstovic of Atalanta during the Serie A match between Atalanta BC and Parma Calcio 1913 at Gewiss Stadium on January 25, 2026 in Bergamo, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

Giacomo Raspadori is back in Serie A after a short-lived, six-month spell in LaLiga with Atletico Madrid. The two-time Scudetto winner struggled to break into Diego Simeone‚Äôs first-team plans in the Spanish capital and was limited to just one start from a possible 18 league matches prior to his joining Atalanta.

Raspadori has already featured in two Serie A matches for Atalanta, starting and scoring in their most recent match against Pisa, which ended in a resounding 4-0 victory for La Dea.

He has already been a regular in Gennaro Gattuso‚Äôs Italy national team squad and now just needs a consistent run of games before becoming a sure-fire pick for the 2026 World Cup squad assuming that Italy qualify.

Official: Lorenzo Lucca joins Nottingham Forest on loan with an option to buy from Napoli (picture: www.nottinghamforest.co.uk)

It had been a disappointing season at Napoli for the towering centre-forward, who has since joined Nottingham Forest on loan with an option to buy.

Napoli brought in both Lucca and Rasmus Hojlund to strengthen their options at centre-forward over the summer, but even after a serious injury to Romelu Lukaku the week before the season began, Lucca was limited to just four starts in Serie A and none since the end of October.

It remains to be seen whether Lucca will become a regular starter in the Premier League under Sean Dyche, but if he is given regular minutes, he will certainly be an option for Gattuso to consider in Italy‚Äôs slightly understocked centre-forward department.

Daniel Maldini wears the Lazio jersey

Another attacker hoping to impress ahead of the World Cup is Daniel Maldini, who joined Lazio on loan with a potential obligation to buy from Atalanta during the January window.

The son of Italy legend Paolo Maldini was limited to just three Serie A starts with Atalanta during the first half of the season, but looks set to be handed more consistent opportunities under Maurizio Sarri at the Stadio Olimpico.

There have even been suggestions that Sarri could look to deploy Maldini as a false nine.

FLORENCE, ITALY ‚Äì JANUARY 27: Marco Brescianini of ACF Fiorentina battles for the ball with Nico Paz of Como 1907 during the Coppa Italia match between of ACF Fiorentina and of Como 1907 at Stadio Artemio Franchi on January 27, 2026 in Florence, Italy. (Photo by Gabriele Maltinti/Getty Images)

Another Italy international who left Atalanta in January was Brescianini, who has joined Fiorentina on loan with an option and potential obligation to buy.

Brescianini has already earned more minutes over his first four games with Fiorentina than he had done in his last four months with Atalanta, earning his first league start since October during La Viola‚Äôs recent 2-1 loss against Napoli.

Brescianini still faces a difficult task to break into the Italy midfield department with stiff competition from the likes of Nicolo Barella, Sandro Tonali, Manuel Locatelli, Davide Frattesi, Bryan Cristante and Samuele Ricci.

Official: Diego Coppola joins Paris FC from Brighton & Hove Albion (@Diegocoppolass via Instagram)

Diego Coppola has taken the decision to move away from the Premier League after six months on the south coast with Brighton and Hove Albion. He had to wait until December to earn his first starts in the English top flight, and has since joined Paris FC on loan, where he will team up with fellow Italy representatives Ciro Immobile and Luca Koleosho.

Coppola has two Italy caps to his name at the age of 22, and will be hoping for more regular minutes in Ligue 1 to challenge the likes of Alessandro Bastoni, Alessandro Buongiorno, Riccardo Calafiori and Gianluca Mancini for a spot in a potential World Cup squad.

title: Newcastle face a must-win reset as they look to bridge the gap to high-flying Brentford
description: Newcastle United host Brentford at St James‚Äô Park this weekend as both sides return their focus to the Premier League.For Newcastle United, the match marks a chance to reset after their Carabao Cup ...
fullText:
Newcastle United host Brentford at St James‚Äô Park this weekend as both sides return their focus to the Premier League.

For Newcastle United, the match marks a chance to reset after their Carabao Cup campaign ended in disappointment during the week.

Eddie Howe‚Äôs side were knocked out convincingly by Manchester City, a result that extended a worrying run of form across competitions.

That defeat leaves Newcastle winless in four matches and searching for rhythm as the league season enters a crucial phase.

Their recent Premier League form has been inconsistent, with defensive lapses and missed chances undermining momentum.

Sitting in mid-table, Newcastle United are not yet out of the European conversation, but the gap to the top six remains a concern.

Returning to St James‚Äô Park may offer some comfort, given the points they have traditionally accumulated at home.

However, recent home defeats have shown that Newcastle‚Äôs fortress is no longer quite as secure as it once appeared.

Standing in their way are a Brentford side arriving with renewed confidence after a statement victory last weekend.

The Bees bounced back from a brief dip in form by beating Aston Villa away from home despite playing an entire half with ten men.

That result underlined Brentford‚Äôs resilience and tactical discipline, qualities that have defined their season.

Keith Andrews‚Äô side have quietly become one of the league‚Äôs most efficient teams over recent weeks.

Only the very top sides have collected more points than Brentford across the last two months.

Defensive solidity has been key, with the Bees conceding fewer goals than almost anyone in that period.

Brentford currently sit just outside the European places and remain firmly in contention for a historic qualification push.

Their away form has also improved significantly, with recent trips yielding both points and confidence.

The reverse fixture earlier this season saw Brentford beat Newcastle United comfortably, which will not have been forgotten.

History, however, leans heavily in Newcastle‚Äôs favour at St James‚Äô Park, particularly against London-based opposition.

Eddie Howe‚Äôs side have generally dominated home meetings with teams from the capital.

That record will be tested by a Brentford side increasingly comfortable against established Premier League clubs.

Newcastle‚Äôs challenge will be to respond positively to cup disappointment without allowing frustration to creep into their performance.

For Brentford, the objective is to keep the game tight and exploit any uncertainty in Newcastle‚Äôs back line.

Their confidence suggests they will not arrive merely to contain.

Both teams have plenty at stake, making this an intriguing contest as the Premier League weekend unfolds.

title: Lindsey Vonn completes first downhill training run at Winter Olympics
description: Lindsey Vonn passed a key test of her damaged knee on Friday after she completed her first downhill training run for the 2026 Winter Olympics.Skiers need to complete one training run in order to compete in the final, with one more session scheduled for Saturday morning.
fullText:
Lindsey Vonn passed a key test of her damaged knee on Friday after she completed her first downhill training run for the 2026 Winter Olympics.

Skiing with a ruptured anterior cruciate ligament in her left knee, Vonn clocked a time of 1min 40.33sec in the American's first official run in Cortina d'Ampezzo, which was delayed for well over an hour due to fog hanging over the Olimpia delle Tofane piste.

Vonn, 41, had been scheduled to take part in Thursday's training run which was cancelled due to heavy snowfall, and on Friday she was forced to wait for her go as fog swept onto the middle section of piste even as bright sunshine shone at the finish line.

Assuming her knee holds up, Vonn will be able to go for her fourth Olympic medal when she approaches the starting gate for Sunday's final of the downhill, the discipline in which she won her sole Olympic gold in 2010.

Skiers need to complete one training run in order to compete in the final, with one more session scheduled for Saturday morning.

Vonn dropped a bombshell on the Milan-Cortina Games on Tuesday when she revealed the extent of her injury, suffered during a heavy crash in the most recent World Cup downhill in Crans Montana a week ago.

She had been in hot form this season, her second since making an astonishing return from retirement in November 2024 following surgery to partially replace her right knee earlier that year.

Vonn has finished on the podium in every World Cup downhill race this season, including two victories in St. Moritz and Zauchensee, and has claimed two more top-three finishes in the super-G.

title: Gold Fields Says Profit Almost Tripled on Bullion Price Rally
description: Gold Fields Ltd. said profit last year likely almost tripled as the miner benefited from bullion‚Äôs record-breaking rally.
fullText: MarketsBy William ClowesSaveGold Fields Ltd. said profit last year likely almost tripled as the miner benefited from bullion‚Äôs record-breaking rally.The Johannesburg-listed company said on Friday that its 2025 earnings are expected to be between $3.87 and $4.11 a share, an increase of 178% to 196% compared with the previous year.

title: Brazil Paper Magnate Touts Photo Venture in Philanthropic Twist
description: Brazilian billionaire David Feffer is best known for helming pulp and paper empire Suzano SA, a family-run industrial group that traces its roots back more than a century. Now he‚Äôs applying his executive chops to a novel philanthropic venture: contemporary photography.
fullText: MarketsBy Rachel Gamarski and Dayanne SousaSaveBrazilian billionaire David Feffer is best known for helming pulp and paper empire Suzano SA, a family-run industrial group that traces its roots back more than a century. Now he‚Äôs applying his executive chops to a novel philanthropic venture: contemporary photography.Feffer is raising funds for an art institute known as ViaFoto, located in the revitalized but long-neglected Baixo Pinheiros neighborhood of S√£o Paulo, Latin America‚Äôs largest city and financial hub. After investing enough to keep the cultural space running for its first two years, the executive and ViaFoto president is seeking $15 million to build a self-sustaining endowment to make it permanent, with a broad base of stakeholders.

title: French Champagne and Perfume Feel the Pain of Trump Tariffs
description: France‚Äôs exports to the US of signature products including champagne and perfume slumped at the end of last year, weighed by President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs and a weaker dollar.
fullText: EconomicsTradeBy William HorobinSaveFrance‚Äôs exports to the US of signature products including champagne and perfume slumped at the end of last year, weighed by President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs and a weaker dollar. Shipments of spirits tumbled 47% on year in the final quarter of 2025, wine fell 39% and perfumes and cosmetics were down 25%, data from the French customs office showed.

title: ECB Monitoring Euro But Rally Not Dramatic, Stournaras Says
description: The European Central Bank is keeping an eye on the euro‚Äôs recent rally but Governing Council member Yannis Stournaras sees no cause for alarm.
fullText: EconomicsCentral BanksBy Mark Schroers, Lizzy Burden, and Jana RandowSaveThe European Central Bank is keeping an eye on the euro‚Äôs recent rally but Governing Council member Yannis Stournaras sees no cause for alarm.‚ÄúWe‚Äôre monitoring exchange rates and monitoring all variables that affect activity and inflation,‚Äù the Greek central-bank chief told Bloomberg Television, stressing that the strengthening since March 2025 is already a part of the ECB‚Äôs projections and that the common currency remains within a historic trading range to the dollar.

title: Mercuria to Start Joint Venture With Tata‚Äôs Trading Unit
description: Mercuria Energy Group has entered into a joint venture with the trading and marketing arm of Indian steel giant Tata Group, both companies said on Friday.
fullText: MarketsBy Archie HunterSaveMercuria Energy Group has entered into a joint venture with the trading and marketing arm of Indian steel giant Tata Group, both companies said on Friday.Pending regulatory approvals, the joint venture is being launched to help Tata International expand its trading business across a wide range of commodities, including oil, gas and environmental products. Tata International is currently involved in procuring and marketing products all over the world for the wider Tata group.

title: Traders Chase ‚ÄòAI Resistant‚Äô Stocks as Disruption Fear Hits Tech
description: A new group of stock winners has emerged as technology shares slide: Companies with businesses that artificial intelligence can‚Äôt replicate.
fullText: TechnologyBy Matthew Griffin, Arvelisse Bonilla Ramos, and Monique MulimaSaveA new group of stock winners has emerged as technology shares slide: Companies with businesses that artificial intelligence can‚Äôt replicate.The S&P 500 Index has dropped 2% this week, pulled down by software companies as investors‚Äô concern that AI will disrupt those business models intensified following the rollout of new tools by startup Anthropic. At the same time, homebuilders, transportation companies and makers of heavy machinery posted strong gains. Consumer staples firms, already considered havens in a downturn, are up 4.7% and heading for their best week since 2022.

title: Momentum Trade Suffers Historic Drawdown Amid Rotation to Value
description: For years, chasing momentum on the stock market has been a winning strategy. It‚Äôs come asunder in the past week.
fullText: MarketsBy Natalia KniazhevichSaveFor years, chasing momentum on the stock market has been a winning strategy. It‚Äôs come asunder in the past week. The momentum trade ‚Äî a strategy of chasing winners and dumping losers ‚Äî suffered the second-steepest drop since the aftermath of the 2020 pandemic Wednesday, worse even than last year‚Äôs DeepSeek selloff and the April tariff swoon. The decline, captured in a Goldman Sachs Group Inc. high-beta momentum basket, undid year-to-date gains in companies that make memory chips, mine metals and rare earth minerals and develop technology applications.

title: Carlyle Profit Beats Estimates as CEO Schwartz Tops 2025 Targets
description: Carlyle Group Inc. exceeded the goals that Chief Executive Officer Harvey Schwartz had set for fee-related earnings and asset growth in 2025, while posting fourth-quarter results that surpassed Wall Street estimates.
fullText: MarketsBy Allison McNeelySaveCarlyle Group Inc. exceeded the goals that Chief Executive Officer Harvey Schwartz had set for fee-related earnings and asset growth in 2025, while posting fourth-quarter results that surpassed Wall Street estimates.Fee-related earnings rose 12% for the year ‚Äî double the target ‚Äî to a record $1.2 billion, the Washington-based firm said in a statement Friday.

title: Thoma Bravo Inserts Lender Anti-Rebellion Clause In Buyout Loan
description: Thoma Bravo just raised the stakes in the tussle between private equity firms and their lenders, by deploying a loan provision to help smoke out creditor rebellions before they even begin.
fullText: MarketsBy Ellen DiMauroSaveThoma Bravo just raised the stakes in the tussle between private equity firms and their lenders, by deploying a loan provision to help smoke out creditor rebellions before they even begin.The firm added the clause in documents tied to a $1.2 billion loan it got from private credit lenders to back the acquisition of cloud-based software provider Vitech by its portfolio company Majesco, according to people familiar with the matter. The provision requires that lenders alert Thoma Bravo within three business days of any attempts they make to coordinate with other creditors in so-called cooperation agreements, the documents viewed by Bloomberg show.

title: CIO Of India‚Äôs Top Equity Fund at ICICI Joins $25 Billion Rival
description: Anish Tawakley, co-chief investment officer for equities at ICICI Prudential Asset Management Co., has quit the firm, according to people familiar with the matter, in a move that reflects intensifying competition for talent as global players expand in the sector.
fullText: MarketsBy Alex Gabriel Simon and Rajesh MascarenhasSaveAnish Tawakley, co-chief investment officer for equities at ICICI Prudential Asset Management Co., has quit the firm, according to people familiar with the matter, in a move that reflects intensifying competition for talent as global players expand in the sector. Tawakley is set to join DSP Asset Managers Pvt. as chief investment officer for their mutual fund business, the people said, asking not to be identified. DSP is a direct competitor to ICICI Prudential AMC in the mutual funds space, and in his new role, Tawakley will oversee assets worth about 2.3 trillion rupees ($25.4 billion).
